Was sind Datenspende-Studien?
Definition ğŸ’¡: Datenspende-Studien sind eine nutzerzentrierte Methode zur Sammlung von Daten:


Nutzende haben das Recht, Daten, die Plattformen Ã¼ber sie sammeln, anzufragen und herunterladen.
Sie kÃ¶nnen ihre Datenpakete (DDPs) via Datenspende-Tools (DDTs), oft im Rahmen von Umfragen, der Wissenschaft zur VerfÃ¼gung stellen.
Forschende nutzen CSS-Methoden zur Filterung, Anonymisierung und Analyse dieser Daten.

Platform-centric (based on platform cooperation)

API (JÃ¼nger, 2021)

User-centric (based on user cooperation and informed consent) or â€œfollow the userâ€ approaches (Caliandro, 2024)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods


Restrictions of platform-centric methods

Discontinuation of APIs (Freelon, 2018)
Concerns about bias (Schatto-Eckrodt, 2022; Ulloa et al., 2025)

User-centric methods become more popular, given â€¦

Changes in law that enable such studies (GDPR, DSA)
Presumably (!) less biased data
Ethical considerations (informed consent)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
What are data donation studies?
Definition ğŸ’¡: Data donation studies are a user-centric method for collecting digital traces:


Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data packages (DDPs) available to science via data donation tools (DDTs), often in the context of surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participantsâ€™ devices before any data is sent to researchers.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, for exampleâ€¦ (Hase et al., 2024)

User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)â€¦

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without â€œrate limitsâ€
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to tracking (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)â€¦

Retrospective & often more longitudinal
Partly additional measurements (e.g., algorithmic inferences)
Anchored in current provisions in law (for issues with tracking, see Edelson & McCoy, 2021)

ğŸ‘‰ but similarly burdensome for participants!

text:
Bias in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking studies, data donation characterized by (Hase et al., 2024; Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024):

Errors in representation (coverage error, non-response error)
Measurement errors (Missing data, Specification error)

ğŸ‘‰ Not necessarily less biased than survey data - but subject to different bias?
ğŸ‘‰ We will talk about this in Session 4ï¸âƒ£.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?
text:
Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?


Low response rates (e.g., Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024)

Behavioral intentions as â€œwillingness to donateâ€ high (79-52% of survey respondents)
Actual behavior as â€œparticipation in data donationâ€ low (37-12% of survey respondents)
Well known intention-behavior gap (Kmetty & Stefkovics, 2025)

Non-response bias
Primary used in non-probability panels (e.g.Â online access panels)
Survey design strategies: For now, ğŸ¤‘ is the only thing that works.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
What are data donation studies?
Definition ğŸ’¡: Data donation studies are a user-centric method for collecting digital traces:


Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data packages (DDPs) available to science via data donation tools (DDTs), often in the context of surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participantsâ€™ devices.
Participants can inspect/delete their data before any data is transferred.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Changes in legal contexts


EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

â€œThe data subject shall have [â€¦] access to the personal dataâ€ (Â§ Art. 15, 1)
â€œThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal dataâ€ (Â§ Art. 15, 3)

According to Â§ Art. 20, users must receive their data â€œin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable formatâ€ (Â§ Art. 20, 1)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Changes in legal contexts

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

â€œThe data subject shall have [â€¦] access to the personal dataâ€ (Â§ Art. 15, 1)
â€œThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal dataâ€ (Â§ Art. 15, 3)

According to Â§ Art. 20, users must receive their data â€œin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable formatâ€ (Â§ Art. 20, 1)

ğŸ‘‰ Solution: Platforms offer data download packages (DDPs), which users can request and download to inspect data.
ğŸ‘‰ Consequence: Researchers uses DDPs as part of user-centric data donation studies.

Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, for exampleâ€¦ (Hase et al., 2024)

User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)â€¦

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without â€œrate limitsâ€
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

Compared to tracking (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)â€¦

Retrospective & often more longitudinal
Partly additional measurements (e.g., algorithmic inferences)
Anchored in current provisions in law (for issues with tracking, see Edelson & McCoy, 2021)

ğŸ‘‰ but similarly burdensome for participants!

text:
Bias in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking studies, data donation characterized by (Hase et al., 2024; Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024):

Errors in representation (e.g., coverage error, non-response error)
Measurement errors (e.g., missing data, specification error)

ğŸ‘‰ Not necessarily less biased than survey data - but subject to different bias?
ğŸ‘‰ We will talk about this in Session 4ï¸âƒ£.

1) Bias in Data Donation Studies

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
What is bias?
Definition ğŸ’¡: Deviations from the true value of a theoretical concept introduced by its measurement (Peytchev, 2013)

Non-systematic errors: random deviations influence variance of estimates
Systematic errors (or: bias): depend on omitted variables

ğŸ‘‰ Bias can influence descriptive results but also attenuate/inflate inferential conclusions.

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
What is bias?

Errors in representation: Who participates in data donation studies?
Errors in measurement: Which latent concepts can we measure with data donation studies?


Source: Image from Boeschoten et al., 2022, p.Â 396

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Errors in representation
For example â€¦


Coverage error: Who is (not) represented in the sampling frame? (e.g., social media users vs.Â YouTube users)
Sampling error: Who is (not) represented in the sample? (e.g., non-probability samples)
Non-response error: Who does (not) want to participate in the data donation?
Compliance error: Who is (not) able to participate in the data donation?

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:

Errors in representation: Quantification

Response rates across study stages
Para data as quality indicators (e.g., speeding)
Non-response bias (e.g.Â traits of survey vs.Â donation participants)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions

A posteriori strategies:

Infrastructure: Integration in probability-based panels
Survey design strategies (e.g., incentives, study framing)
DDT design (e.g.Â UX-perspective)

Post hoc strategies:

Statistical modeling (e.g., weighting, see Pak et al., 2022)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions
For now: limited studies, limited success of existing solutions

Source: Figure from Hase & Haim (2024)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Errors in measurement
For example â€¦


Construct (in-)validity: How do DDP variables relate to latent measurements? (e.g., likes vs.Â political participation)
Measurement error: How correct is data in our DDP? (e.g., missing data)
Extraction error: Did we extract all relevant files and variables?

text:

text:

Para data (e.g., failed uploads)
Correlation between self-reported and observed behavior
Multi Trait Multi Method (MTMM) approaches (Cernat et al., 2024)
Estimation of misclassification effects (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)

title: Data Donation Studies: COMPTEXT Workshop
text:
Errors in representation: Solutions

A posteriori strategies:

Talk to everyone (e.g., IRB, Data Strward)
Repeated testing & DDP download
Simulate downstream errors (Bosch et al., 2024)

Post hoc strategies:

Multiverse approaches
Statistical error correction (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)
Error documentation (Gebru et al., 2021)
